I am sure I would not, for a thousand guineas, that it happened in my house; and I pity his poor Lady, of all things.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: This is a master stroke, indeed, Mrs. Frankly. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why really, if this be the case, I do think his poor Lady is to be pitied—Why, man, the honey-moon is hardly over yet, and I declare that I was constant to my wife, for near a year after we were married—But then I was in love, mightily in love, d'ye see—However, I don't think that either you or I have any right to interfere in his Lordship's amours, Mrs. Frankly, and a forcible detainer is contrary to law—Besides, I have a small matter of business to confer with you upon myself, at present.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Which I will by no means interrupt, Governor, and heartily wish you may settle it to your mutual satisfaction. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
I shall be home to supper, my Lord. I
have bespoke a couple of little plates to be dressed after our India fashion. My Lady has ordered the rest, I suppose. I make bold to hope, my dear little widow, that you understand something of cookery—for they absolutely know nothing of seasoning their meat, in England. I have some excellent receipts of poor Bab's by me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: How could I be so weak a wretch, as to imagine I could retain Lord Seaton's affections. He is, alas! gone from me for ever. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: You seem mightily disturbed, I think— I wonder she does not say any thing of the five hundred pounds. (Aside.) No bad news, I hope, from your lawyers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Here comes another of my plagues.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Your servant, Mr. Bull. Now, my little widow, speak to Sammy, there—he'll make your mind easy, I believe. He is certain of your success, and tells me that the suit will be determined, to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Trial put off, till next term.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Never the worse for that, Master Bull. Stocks may rise, by that time, perhaps. You did not sell out—

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Before dinner.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: How unlucky! But, however, it don't much signify, as it happens, as I shall want that, and another five hundred, for Squeezem, this very night.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Money disposed of to lawyers. Did not know of the delay, till it was expended. Won't refund. Must be refreshed again, first day of term.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Refreshed! I actually believe you invent words only to put me in a passion. This refreshment has almost thrown me into a fever.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Don't be obstinate—speak to him, or we shall be undone, Maria. (Aside to Mrs. Frankly.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: No matter—I care not what becomes of you, myself, or all the world.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, don't take on so, neither— Though delays are dangerous, to be sure, as well as mortifying.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Wants comfort, mightily.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And she shall have it, Sammy, eh! But, let's see—Why the term don't sit till November next—That's a plaguy long day, to be sure—I thought to have been married directly—and if one was certain that this same law suit, d'ye see, was quite a hollow thing—

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Quite hollow.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Say you so? Why then, if my pretty widow pleases, we'll be married to-morrow, and dine at the London Tavern, or the Crown and Anchor, or wherever else she pleases—You shall have your choice, d'ye see—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: All places upon earth are equal now to me—for none can quiet my distracted mind.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: (To Bull.) Why I don't rightly understand that, now—Didn't she whisper something about distractions? eh! There's no madness in the family, I hope.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Madness! No, no, no—Distracted with joy, on her wedding-day, that's all—Pretty compliment, if rightly taken—Has wit at her fingers end—Recover yourself, or we are ruined.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Why that is witty, to be sure, but it did
not strike me, I own, at first. (To Mrs. Frankly.) Well, but compose yourself, d'ye see, for too much joy may sometimes be hurtful.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Mine will not be immoderate, Sir, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: That's very discreetly said, now. I am impatient for to-morrow. I'll go directly to bespeak the dinner, and get the licence ready. Come, Mr. Bull, you shall go with me. But won't your niece give me one kiss?—

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: May command it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: D'ye tell me so; by your leave then. (Kisses her.) Her breath smells like Otto of roses. By the way you shall have a bottle of the best that ever was made in Persia, to-morrow morning. The Great Mogul has not as good. But, come along, Master Bull, I have many matters, and money matters, to talk to you about; but those little twinklers put every thing out of my head. I shall want a thousand pounds for the good of the nation, this very night, d'ye see. I have promised to send it to Squeezem, and Ned Anderson never yet broke his word; and that's a bold expression for one of my age, let me tell you. I am not a man of words, but of deeds, my little widow, and I hope you'll like me the better, therefore—eh! and so adieu, My pretty, pretty Poll. (Singing.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: I am glad they are gone—I could not conquer my confusion! Detested be the hour I tried the art to wear a smile upon my cheek, while rage and grief tear my distracted soul.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Lord, Madam! what a sad bustle has been here this afternoon; I am afraid we are all blown up with the Governor, as I hear he was by at some part of it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Lucy, I am undone for ever! I have lost Lord Seaton's heart, and all other misery is equal to me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I wish you had no other misfortune to complain of, Madam. Hearts are soon won, and soon lost. It is not love, but money, that should take up your thoughts at present. In short, all your creditors are alarmed, and you had much better think of the only way you have to quiet them, by becoming the Governor's lawful wife immediately.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: I do not want your advice, but your pity, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Pity! Charity begins at home, Madam; and for that matter, I think myself as much to be pitied as other people.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: (Pausing.) Get me a pen and ink; I'll write to Lord Seaton directly.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: If you have lost his heart, a pen and ink will hardly bring it back again; but they are on your table in the dressing room; and if I might advise, it would be, for the present, at least, to drop a connection, which, by ruining you, may injure my own interests. (Carelessly.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: And pray, Mrs. Lucy, how came your interests to be any way connected in this matter?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Why really, Madam, to tell you the truth, I apprehend, that if any unlucky circumstance
should break off your match with the Governor, it would then be out of your power to reward my many long and faithful services.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Insolent wretch! needed there this addition to my misfortunes!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: People who bring on their own misfortunes, Madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Are to be insulted by their servants, it seems—But I will no longer bear your insolence.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nor I your distresses, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: My affability has been mistaken, I find, or you had not dared to insult me thus— But as for the extraordinary merits you boast of, I shall think it not the least injustice to leave such virtues to their own reward. Prepare your accounts instantly, nor dare appear before me again, but to give them in. Ungrateful woman! Exit.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Prepare your accounts. Yes, that's easily done. I have them pretty well by heart already. I'll give them in, to-morrow morning, to the Governor, and leave you two to cast them up together, at your next meeting. Ungrateful woman, too, I am called. 'Tis fine talking, truly, about gratitude, and such stuff, because one won't spend their whole life in poverty with her—and that I foresee will be her fate, at last. In love with my Lord, forsooth! and every thing must be sacrificed to that girlish passion. Why, if the Governor should marry her to-morrow, 'tis ten to one but she'd be in the heighth of the mode in a week; in Doctor's Commons in a fortnight; and a beggar before the honey-moon was over. But I'll prevent that mischief, at least, by exposing her to his Excellency; and if he is bent upon matrimony, right or wrong,
there are people who think me handsomer than my mistress; and if he has but half as much sense, as money, he may possibly be of the same opinion too. Exit.

sp.speaker: COLONEL.
sp.p: MY search has hitherto been vain; but I have just now heard that my sister Freeman is expected soon in town; and if female friendships are not, as Lord Seaton says, an empty name, she will probably know something of my dear Charlotte's situation or abode. My engagement here, for this evening, puts it out of my power to enquire about her, to-night; but to morrow early I shall call at her house—Mrs. Markam!

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: You are welcome to England, Sir, but am sorry to acquaint you that my Lady happens to be so much indisposed, at present, that she must deny herself the pleasure of seeing you, for this evening.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am extremely sorry for your Lady's illness, Mrs. Markam. This sudden attack alarms me for her.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p:
O, by no means sudden, Sir. My Lady has been ill of the same disorder, ever since she has been married. I wonder, for my part, how she has been able to bear it so patiently; but she is convinced, at last, and I hope she'll pluck up a
spirit now, and not suffer herself to be imposed upon, any longer.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I do not understand you. She seemed to be in perfect health, at dinner.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and if she was, she has had enough in conscience to have made her sick, since then. She'll believe me, another time, I fancy. I am not apt to be mistaken, whatever she may be. I am sure it is a scandalous thing for him that has such a charming Lady of his own, and has not been married quite two months yet—And that pretty demure Miss too, that my Lady was so fond of—But I never liked her, for my part, and always said that smooth water—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Prithee, Mrs. Markam, explain yourself— You alarm me, extremely.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: I beg your honour's pardon—I forgot that you were in love with Miss Melville formerly, or to be sure I would not have said a word against her before you; but then I was so enraged with my Lord for slighting his good Lady, that I could not command myself—Though for certain it is no affair of mine, after all; and I must beg, Sir, that you would not mention any thing I have said, for the world; for my Lady would never forgive me, if she knew that I spoke of it to any one.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am on the rack. (Aside.) The only way then to insure my secrecy, Mrs. Markam, is by making me a thorough confidant; for as yet I do not comprehend what Miss Melville has to do with either your Lady's illness, or your Lord's unkindness. She quitted this house, I have been informed, before they were married; and they have both assured me they have neither of them seen her, since.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Does my Lord say so?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: He most certainly did.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Why then great folks have a patent— I suppose; for as sure as I stand here, my Lady detected his Lordship and Miss Melville together, this very afternoon—And was that their first tête à tête, think you?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: By heaven, I cannot give credit to this story—I should still think it impossible, though Lord Seaton and Miss Melville themselves were both to confess it.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, I am frightened out of my wits—It mayn't be true, as you say, after all. I could bite my tongue off for being so nimble. I wish heartily I had been dumb.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If you have idly slandered Miss Melville, you deserve to be so for life. But I will have this matter explained immediately—Where is Lord Seaton?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: O dear, good Colonel, for heaven's sake don't be in a passion—there might be no harm done, to be sure—he was only kneeling at her feet, when my Lady happened to come into the room.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Insidious, base dissembler!

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Why to be sure he has a dissembling tongue, and every one thought that he was in love with my Lady, before he married her, except herself—But she, it seems, had her suspicions that he liked Miss better, and that made my Lady so cold to her, that she hardly opened her lips to her for a great while before she left the house. (A rapping at the door.) Here's my Lord a coming, I fear.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p:
O dear, merciful Colonel, have compassion, and don't betray me now. Consider I am but a poor servant, Sir, and indeed Miss Melville was always very kind to me; and if your honour
will but forgive me, this once, I promise never to speak another word against her, while I have breath —But I must run, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And well you have rewarded her kindness. But when persons of rank and education set an example of meanness and ingratitude, we are not to expect to meet with their opposite virtues, in an inferior class.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: O Charles, I am glad to meet you. I have a perfect novel of extraordinary incidents to communicate to you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And I am glad, my Lord, that we are met, and that you are in such a communicative disposition, as I have a question to ask you, that must be answered.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Must, Colonel!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, it must be resolved—Where is Miss Melville?

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: That question, Colonel, neither must, nor can, be resolved, by me—I know not where she is.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Can it be possible you should be mean enough to attempt to screen an act of perfidy and baseness, beneath the flimsy subterfuge of falsehood! But 'twill not do, my Lord; we must not part, till you inform me where Miss Melville is; and from her lips, which used to be the oracles of truth, I will learn all the rest.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You really astonish me, Sir, with a language as little becoming you to use, as for me to bear.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
The man who has deserved such language ought to bear it. Courage and falsehood never
dwelt together; and when the mind is so far debased, as to forge a tale to impose upon a friend, all pretence to bravery is but a jest—a madman's phrenzy, or a coward's rage.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I can endure this insolence, no longer. This roof is your protection, for the present, Sir; but quit it instantly, and let us quickly meet where the vile term you have now used, may light on him who most deserves it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Unworthy as I think your Lordship's conduct, I cannot yet refuse your appointment—To-morrow morning I shall call upon you—till then, farewel, my Lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You shall find me ready, Sir. How was it possible for him to know that I had seen Miss Melville? When I came in the servant told me my wife was ill, and had not seen the Colonel— She could not, therefore, nay, she would not, tell him—But it matters not, at present, who informed him. I never meant to injure him. I did not know of his passion for Charlotte, till after I was married; and had I, on his return, acknowledged each circumstance that ever passed between us, he could not have condemned me. How weak and culpable is want of frankness? This alone has involved me in all my difficulties.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: From Mrs. Frankly, my Lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p:
Notwithstanding inhumanity, unkind treatment of me—fondness triumphed—still weak enough—Possibly hazard— breaking off—advantageous match—A man I detest—But what is worldly interest, &c.
Mary Frankly.

Despicable, yet unhappy woman! The artful meanness of her conduct, this evening, has sunk her below my pity. This marriage that she hints at, is thrown out merely to draw me to her lure—But 'tis in vain, for I shall never see, or think of her, again. Indeed I have something more material to take up my thoughts, at present—This hasty conduct of Ramsay's distresses me extremely—But 'tis first necessary that I should clear Miss Melville's conduct to my wife—They must be mutual sufferers by the continuance of Lady Seaton's mistake; and she, at least, deserves all my endeavours to restore her peace. Though I cannot account for her following me to Mrs. Frankly's this evening. But grant it were a fault, 'tis her first to me, and mine I confess to have been manifold against her—Who's there?

Ask Markam if her Lady be in her dressing-room, and let her know that I desire to speak with her. [Exit Waters.] In what different points of view do the same objects present themselves, at different times, before us! The seriousness of my present situation has removed the veil which the false notions and loose manners of the present world had spread over my thoughts and actions. I see now the impropriety, nay, the inhumanity, of my whole conduct to Lady Seaton, and wish, though perhaps too late, that it may yet be in my power to make her every atonement.
You seem alarmed, Madam; but lay aside your fears—You have nothing to apprehend.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: The consciousness, my Lord, of having offended you, though most inadvertently, must certainly render me unhappy.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: The extraordinary step you took this evening, Madam, appears to be but little consistent with the delicacy of the sentiment you now express.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: If you will condescend to hear my motives for it, my Lord, you will not judge so hardly of me. I then thought Miss Melville innocent—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: And so, by heaven, she is.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I repeat it; and though to support my assertion, I shall be obliged to accuse myself, yet will I do her merit the justice it deserves. On my return from Italy, at the same moment I beheld ye both—

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: Stop there, my Lord—too well, alas! I know who then won the preference in your affections.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Passion is involuntary, Madam; but I had hopes that reason, which directed my addresses to you, would have conquered that partiality.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: Impossible, my Lord, I fear; and blushing own, that though I perceived your attachment to my rival, I yet nourished in my breast the same to you—By vain self-love misled, I fondly thought I might perhaps inspire the tenderness I felt—My weakness has been punished as it ought!

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You judge yourself too severely, Madam—'Tis I alone am culpable.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: We both deceived ourselves, my Lord, and both have been to blame.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p:
I would not wish, Madam, to involve you in my errors, and am sincerely sorry you should have suffered by them—Let me now proceed—
After some unsuccessful struggles with myself, I at length determined to confess my prepossession for Miss Melville, and break off the treaty with you— I wrote to her, accordingly, on the subject—Her answer was consistent with that worth which dignifies her whole conduct. She owned ingenuously that her heart had been preingaged, but also generously assured me, that were it perfectly free, she could never have availed herself of my preference in her favour, to your prejudice.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: Generous, charming girl! how have I injured her!

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I have reason to believe that she left this house, in hopes her absence might efface my passion, and suffer your beauty and merits, Madam, to produce the effect they must naturally have had upon a disengaged heart. From that moment, till this evening, and that by accident merely, I declare I never saw or heard from her; and was, at that instant, only intreating her return to you again. If therefore you have conceived one doubt to her dishonour, banish it for ever from your mind.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: I never had a doubt, my Lord, of Charlotte's worth, nor was it jealousy, but friendship, that brought me to be a witness of that scene which first disturbed my confidence in her—But you have now restored it, and if I knew where to direct my course, I would this moment fly to intreat her pardon, as I do yours; for I have injured you beyond the hope of an atonement—'Twas selfish vanity inspired the cruel wish of being yours, without the power of paying back the happiness I received.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p:
Nay, Madam, do not speak so humbly—The polite attentions which I paid you, joined to your own personal charms and merits, might,
without vanity, have made you think that you possessed my love; whilst I, false to your happiness, as well as to my own, knew but too well I had not then a heart to give.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: In vain, my Lord, you kindly strive to set my mind at peace, and reconcile me to an error that has been fatal to us both, I fear.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I am too sensible how far I have wronged you, to bear this generous contest; but may I hope the frankness I have shewn, in thus discovering to you the weakness of my conduct, will at least assure you of my confidence and esteem.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: I ask no more, my Lord, and shall ever study to deserve them.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: The kindness and condescension of that speech, Lady Seaton, merits much more, and has awaked my tenderness—But is that worthy your acceptance, now?

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: The world were well exchanged for such a treasure!

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Accept then, thou most deserving of thy sex, a heart more surely thine, than if it had first been led to you by passion only, for that is liable to change; but kindness and worth, like yours, must naturally inspire unfading love.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: My tears alone can speak my joy! my gratitude!

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Thus let me wipe away the precious drops, and with them all remembrance of my past follies. (Embraces her.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Why, hey dey, what wind blows now! but no matter, this at least is as it should be, and
just so I hope little spousey and I will spend our time together. I have a business of consequence to communicate to your Lordship—I do all above board, d'ye see, and as I thought you were dull and alone, I came up to discourse you a little—I am glad to see you recovered, niece, they told me you were sick, and kept your chamber.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: I am much better, Sir, and now may truly say that I am well and happy.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And I am truly glad of both, my dear niece.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: (To Lady Seaton.) Can it be possible, my dear, that, generous as your nature is, a woman can sincerely pardon a preference once shewn to another?

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: The doubt's unkind—but ask yourself, my Lord, Can there be any thing in nature more pleasing to a generous mind, than to have something to forgive?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why this is downright making love, my Lord, and renders me the more impatient to talk of my own affairs, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Retire, my dear, and rest assured that all my future life shall be devoted to the continuance of our present happiness.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: Your kind intentions have secured its permanence, and made my bliss complete. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: (Lord Seaton looking after her.) How little do we foresee the evils that await us! the apprehensions of what that amiable woman may have yet to suffer, on my account, disturb me much.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Why for that matter, my Lord, I am a little disturbed myself, d'ye see, or else I would not have troubled you—You must know then, that I am going to be married out of hand, directly, and
my friend Bull, who was to have given away the bride, writes me word that he can't attend my wedding—but if your Lordship will be so good to supply his place, d'ye see—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I heartily wish you joy, Governor, and will readily accept the office; but pray who is our aunt to be?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: One that you have seen, very lately, my Lord, but you don't know half her good qualities, perhaps; she is the modestest, most reserved little rogue—and a man, at my time of life, you know, and in these times too, has no business with a fine gay flaunting Lady, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Not much, truly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, no, Ned Anderson is no such simpleton! I have chosen a sober, discreet, young creature, very handsome withal—that will mind family matters, and be proud of her husband's company, d'ye see—Can't you guess, now, my Lord? there are but few, in these days, that can answer such a description, I fancy —

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Very few, I believe, Governor, and I happen to be wholly unacquainted with any of that small number.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why then not to puzzle you farther, my Lord, the first letter of her name is Frankly—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Frankly!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why yes, my Lord, the pretty widow, at whose house we happened to meet, this evening —she was mightily concerned for my niece, I assure you; for she is very strict, and was greatly out of sorts at your behaviour. And by the way you ought to be a little more cautious in your conduct, and not expose yourself, by pursuing a girl into a strange house, d'ye see—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I am much obliged to you for your advice, Sir. But pray will you give me leave to ask you by what means you became acquainted with this same paragon of virtue?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why my good friend, honest Sam. Bull, the broker, having in the course of our business together, conceived a particular regard for me, introduced me to his niece, some time ago—she has a jointure of six hundred per annum, and he was plaguily afraid that some young fop might run away with her, and use her ill; he therefore recommended me as one that would be a kind of a father to her, d'ye see—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Yes, that I do see, very plainly, indeed—But pray is your good friend Mr. Bull a broker for marriages, as well as stocks, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, no, my Lord, he made no matter of business of it, in the least; for tho' he understands making a bargain as well as any man in the Alley, he never once talked of a settlement—all, all is left to my own honour—but he knows his man, that's pretty plain, I think—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Very apparent, truly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Do you think your Lordship can be ready to attend upon us to church by nine, to-morrow morning?

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: To-morrow, Governor!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Yes, to-morrow is to be the happy day, nephew.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: As circumstances are drawing so near a conclusion, Sir, I will be free enough to tell you, that you must not think of Mrs. Frankly, for a wife.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Why that is frank and free enough, to be sure, my Lord; but I must have some better reason than a mere ipse dixit, as Nicholas calls it. I
have always been a man of honour, to the ladies, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I approve your chivalry, Governor, but with this reserve, that you are sure your Ladies be also Ladies of honour, on their part; lest your knight-errantry should be dishonoured by your galantry; and as it is happily not yet too late, I may venture to tell you that your present Dulcinea is totally devoid of such a character.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Not too late! Ay, truly, but it is, tho', for I have not even so much as an acknowledgment under her hand, for five hundred pounds I lent her, this very morning, to fee her lawyers; and I gave her a pair of ear-rings, not a month ago, that cost me five hundred pounds more. But if she has no honour, 'tis well she has some land, at least. Bull assures me that her jointure is a good six hundred, per annum.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: What! upon his estate, Governor?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I never heard he had one.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Nor I either, I promise you; and I rather doubt his having a foot of ground to stand upon, in the Alley, much longer.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Don't say so, my Lord; you'll break my heart. If Bull has waddled out a lame duck, I may be an undone man, for aught I see.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Matters may not be so bad as you apprehend; but at any rate I think you have reason to rejoice at having escaped being Mrs. Frankly's dupe, at least.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Rejoice! at what? that I have been deceived and disappointed in the woman I had set my heart upon, when it is too late in life to think of mending myself elsewhere. But I'll have my money and my jewels from her, if they are to be had, d'ye see, before we part.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You'll find it rather a difficult matter, I fancy, to recover your property out of such hands; but I wish you success, and a good night, with all my heart, Governor. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: A good night! fine talking, truly, after you have broke my rest. I don't believe I shall be able to get a wink of sleep, this month to come. I think I am even more disturbed, now, than when my poor Bab died, and I remember that I lay awake, that night, almost three hours, tho' I had not lost a farthing, neither.

sp.speaker: Pomp.
sp.p: A young Lady desires to see you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: What! a young Lady, did you say?

sp.speaker: Pomp.
sp.p: Here she is herself, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: So, Mrs. Lucy, what! does your mistress want another five hundred, to refresh her lawyers, to-morrow, and has sent you to wheedle me out of it? Eh!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No really, Sir, I am not the person you take me for. I would scorn to join in imposing on so worthy a gentleman, as your Excellency.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Worthy me no worthies, Mrs. Abigail, it won't do, I can tell you—she has mistaken her man, d'ye see—I am not so easily imposed upon as she may imagine.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I am sure, Sir, it has broke my heart, to see how you have been cheated and deceived, both by Mr. Bull and Mrs. Frankly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
You acknowledge it, then. But I'll shew them the difference immediately, and Bull may look
out for some fitter dupe to repair the honour and fortune of his family, by marrying his niece.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: His niece! why that, indeed, sounds well, Sir—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why, is not Bull her uncle, girl?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No more related to her, Sir, than you are. The very jewels you gave her, Sir, are gone, past redemption. Sold, Sir, to supply her uncle's necessities, and will never more be heard of, believe me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I am struck dumb with amazement! But, if Bull be not her uncle, why should she bestow him her jewels, d'ye see?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, there may be closer connections, than relations, I suppose, in the world.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I shall be petrified! Why he is not her galant, sure, is he?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I scorn to speak scandal, Sir; but if he be, he is not her only one, I can assure you; for Lord Seaton is another—Tho' the passion happens unluckily to be all on the wrong side there, I can answer for it—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: My hair stands an end at her wickedness! As for you, girl, there take my purse, as a reward for your honesty, d'ye see—but never let me see you, or any thing that belongs to your mistress, more.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: So then, the best part of my scheme is disappointed, I find—I don't believe that he has even looked at me. (Aside). I thank your Excellency, and wish you a good night, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Good-bye to ye. Good-bye to ye. Get you out. Get you out. (Pushing her off.) In love with Lord Seaton! O the devil, the devil! what now in nature can make people such rogues! one
hears, every day, here, of such pranks as would taint the very air of India, and breed a pestilence there. I'll go back, I'll go back again, in the first ship that sails, and spend the remainder of my life among men whose words are bonds, and where the ties of honour require no laws to bind them—But first I'll go maul my happy—I'll break her night's rest, for her, and her heart too, if I can. The intriguing gipsey! Exit.

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.p: I HAVE had a devilish bad night of it. If I had vented my rage, I might have got some sleep, perhaps—but she was in bed, and would not see me, forsooth.—Plaguy modest, to be sure. But I'll make bold to break her morning slumbers. I'll rouse her, that I will. Get me my breakfast, quickly—There's no good in fasting, d'ye see— Dispatch, I say, or I shall go without it—My rage will burst me—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I grieve to see your Excellency so much inflated with choler—but I obey. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why, how now, Mr. Squeezem!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: O, Sir, you have made a fine hand of your affairs, with your boasted punctuality—We have no bonds, in India, forsooth. Commend me to the persons who are not ashamed to set their names to a piece of stamped paper. They are the men to do business with.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Why, what can be the meaning of all this! Did not Bull carry you the money, last night?
And were you not to set out with the sun, this morning?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: No, really, Sir, Mr. Bull did not bring me a farthing; but I believe he has carried that, and himself off together, by the light of the moon; for he was not to be found at his own house, at day-break, when I called there; and I fancy that neither sun or moon will ever see him in England again.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: So then 'tis pretty plain that I have been completely gulled, jilted, bulled and beared, by a professing scoundrel and a pretty face—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: What signifies all this, to your seat in the house? Honours, Sir, don't spring up like mushrooms, in a night—They are not to be had when, where, and how you please.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, Sir, nothing is to be had as I please. —All's lost—all's gone—I see it—I know it—I'm an object of pity, Mr. Squeezem. So if you'l please to refund me the thousand I advanced to you—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Why surely, Sir, you are not in earnest. Refund, quotha! Why, Sir, it was all gone, swallowed, eaten and drank up, in one day. Electioneering is your only true sinking fund, Governor. Potwallopers refund!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Sir, your Excellency's meal is prepared within.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Go eat it then—I have no appetite left.— Potwalloppers! a thousand pounds potwalloped, in a day! impossible! I'll cram them with turtle, 'till they burst, d'ye see, and defy them to do it.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: It is reported that Anthony and Cleopatra expended, at one supper—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Choke them with their supper, impertinent—I shall run mad, with vexation. What! a thousand pounds in a day, and not to have either my money, or myself returned, after all!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, how impatiently you talk! Why many, and many an honest gentleman has spent ten thousand, in the same way, and had no more for his money, than you have.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Get out of my sight, I advise you, while I can yet command my temper. A thousand pounds at a meal!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: As you seem a little indisposed, at present, Sir, I shall take your advice, and retire; but if any other snug, convenient seat should offer, in futuro, Sir, you may freely command the services of your most obedient, Bartholomew Squeezem.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: You and your disservices may go to the vengeance together. I have got enough of electioning, and of courting too, for life, I think. I'll see Mrs. Frankly, this instant, and have justice on that villain Bull, if 'tis to be had in the land. Was there ever so unfortunate a man as I am! disappointed in every thing—plundered by every body! What a pack of troubles have I brought upon myself, without designing the least manner of mischief to any one alive! Exit.

Bull's absconding, and Lucy's deserting me, in so critical a situation, have happened most unluckily.
What excuse can I make, for Bull's absence, to the Governor? He was here late, last night, and raving at being refused admittance▪ Fear of detection, what a curse art thou! O could the young and artless mind but know the agonies that dwell with guilt, it would prefer the humblest lot with peace, to all that splendid vice can e'er bestow.—But what have I to do with such reflections, now! No reply yet from Seaton—his cold unkindness stabs me to the heart—My dear Governor—

div3.stage: Enter the GOVERNOR, in a passion.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Thou worse than a vulture, or a kite— thou cruellest, and most ungrateful of women! I know not where to begin, nor in what language to speak of you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: (What can this mean! Lucy has betrayed me, I fear. Aside.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I am thoroughly acquainted with your arts, I know all your history at full length, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: I hope it has entertained you, Sir, for you seem to be much engaged with it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Don't offer to interrupt me—Let me speak, I say. That villain Bull, that fellow that passed for your uncle, is no more related to you than the Great Mogul. He is your galant, it seems, and you meant to marry me, merely to make his fortune.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Mr. Bull of all creatures, my galant! This is too ridiculous, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
'Tis true, for all that, as honest Lucy has assured me—and the very jewels I gave you,
nay, perhaps, the money I advanced to see your lawyers, ungenerous woman, have been all sacrificed to him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Lucy! and so honest Mrs. Lucy is your informer, Sir! I give you joy of your authority.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Don't answer me, I say, thou harpy—I have not brought half my charges against you, yet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: I shall not attempt to answer you, indeed, Sir, as you really appear to be quite out of your reason, at present, and there is no arguing with a madman.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: If I am mad, 'tis you that have made me so—but your insolence shall not defend you. I will expose you and your good uncle Bull, to the whole world. I won't confine myself to one quarter of it—all India shall know how you have used me. Where are the ear-rings I gave you? Where are my jewels, I say? shew them to me, this instant. I insist upon seeing them, at least.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: How is that possible, pray, if I have already given them to Mr. Bull?—Delirious!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Her assurance amazes me—I thought she would have fallen at my feet and implored my pardon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: No, really, Sir—injured innocence has a right to resent—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Injured innocence!—that word has almost choked me—This is too much—Then, Madam Injured Innocence, I have accused you wrongfully, it seems—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: So you may possibly find, Sir, when perhaps it may be too late to repent of it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And why the plague don't you justify yourself then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: So I would, Sir, if you were in a condition to hear reason.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Well, well—speak—speak freely.—I am perfectly cool—quite calm, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Hear me, then. All this rage of yours proceeds from Lucy's having trumped up a false story—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: A false story! Hell and the furies! then prove it so, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Don't swear, Sir—remember you are perfectly cool—quite calm, you know.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Well, well, I am so, I had forgot—Go on, Madam, now, without interruption.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Then first, Sir, give me leave to ask you if you are acquainted with the reason of Lucy's quitting my service?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, because she could not bear to be a witness of your imposing on me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Just the reverse, Sir—I turned her out of my house, last night, for abusing you, ungenerous as you are.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Abusing me! Why, what could the minx find to say against me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: How can you think, said she, of burying your youth, beauty, and fortune, in the arms of your grandfather! when there are so many—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Grandfather! confound the jade.—Let me hear no more of her impertinence, but come to the point, Madam; Where is your uncle, and where are my diamonds, d'ye see?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p:
Mr. Bull, Sir, is gone into Wiltshire, to bring up a witness to prove my dear Mr. Frankly's last will—and as to the diamonds, Sir,
Lucy, you say, has given you a full account of them.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and a receipt in full, too, Madam—your pretended uncle has carried them into Wiltshire to bribe your evidence, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Mr. Bull has them, then! mighty well, Sir. And if I was to produce them now, what would you say, then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Say! why really in such a case, Madam, I should say—hang me, if I know what I should say—but 'tis absolutely impossible—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Then not to satisfy, but to shock you, look there— (opening a casket. He starts.)— Now take them back again, Sir, for as I prized them more as a token, than a gift, they have lost their value with your unkindness. (Weeps.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I am confounded! I am dead! the very jewels I gave her, that's certain! That vile jade Lucy! I see you are innocent, Madam, and must implore your pardon for having doubted it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: You ought not to have doubted it, Sir, nor have ventured to insult a woman of honour upon the testimony of a wretch, whom common sense might have informed you I should not have discarded, had it been in her power to have hurt me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why to be sure I might have thought of that, Madam, but you can't conceive what a pack of plausible lies she told me.—She said you were in love too with Lord Seaton, who despised you— nay his Lordship spoke to your disadvantage himself, also, and first cautioned me against marrying you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p:
But surely now any person of common sense, Sir, would have considered his endeavour to prevent it, as a proof rather of love,
than of hate—I soon perceived he had gained Lucy over to his interest, which was the chief reason of my discharging her; in revenge for which she invented all those abominable stories, and you were weak enough to believe them.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I have been weak enough, to be sure; but you shall find now that I am perfectly satisfied.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: You allow then, that you have been in the wrong, Sir—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: And that you have been duped by a woman—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Shamefully—I see it, now—I feel it— Yes, yes, I have been duped, indeed, with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: And you really do repent of your credulity.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Repent! shall hang myself if you do not forgive me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Well, well, then, I do forgive you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And I ask your pardon, again and again —So now let us kiss and friends—kiss and friends, for life, d'ye see. I shall think every minute an age 'till we are one—we'll be married, this very day. Let's lose no time, d'ye see. I'll step home and bring Nicholas, directly, to give you away, and do you run in and prepare, so that there may be no waiting when we call on you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: You trespass on my fondness, which pleads your cause so strongly; for had you less love, you would have had less jealousy; and the excess of one should ever atone for the violence of the other. And so I shall be ready to attend you, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why that's very good-natured, and very true, too. Yes, indeed, I do love her monstrously, or I should not have been so jealous. But for all this I shall discourse my Lord Seaton a little, before I am married; for I neither can, nor will be satisfied, till I have made him recant his calumny. Exit.

div3.head: SCENE, Mrs. FREEMAN's House.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: The hurry and agitation I passed thro', yesterday evening, have discomposed my spirits so much that I find it impossible to rest. Mrs. Freeman is not yet up, so that I have sufficient leisure to reflect on the extraordinary adventures of yesterday, which I confess appear to me, now, more like a vision than a fact. I am impatient till all this mistery is explained, that I may have an opportunity of clearing my conduct to my amiable friend. If the weight only of an imputed crime be so hard to bear, what a burden must real guilt be! Lord Seaton said something, I think, of Colonel Ramsay. I dare not flatter my hopes about his arrival, as Mrs. Freeman knows nothing of it yet. But see, beyond a doubt my wishes are accomplished— Enter Colonel RAMSAY. You are welcome to England, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
I have been so long absent, Madam, that I own myself rather surprized at your recollection of a person whom I hoped, for your own sake,
you had totally forgotten; and you must pardon me if I also add that my wonder is a good deal increased, by seeing you at present in Mrs. Freeman's house.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: What can this mean! Surely 'tis you, Sir, who have forgotten both yourself and me, or after two tedious years of absence it were not possible we should meet thus.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I fancy, Madam, that the absence of an injured lover does not appear tedious to those who enjoy the presence of a favoured one. Lord Seaton, Madam, has sufficiently consoled you for my loss.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Lord Seaton!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You seem surprized; but I am too well informed of your connection. However, Madam, I did not mean to upbraid, or intrude upon you, now. I came here only to see my sister, and have but a short time to spare to her, from a very particular and pressing engagement.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Be your engagements what they may, Sir, I have a right to expect you should explain the meaning of your present conduct towards me, as far at least as it respects my character.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You speak, Madam, as if you thought you still retained the power you once had over me; but you have forfeited it, and I am no longer now the dupe of my own weakness, or of your deceit.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: O Ramsay, how have I deserved this treatment?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
(I cannot bear her tears. Aside.) I wish not, Madam, to offend or wound you—you are mistress of your own actions, and all I shall further say, upon this subject, is, that had your new engagement
been more for your own honour, your perfidy might have been more pardonable to one who respected your character, as much as he admired your person.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I do not comprehend you, Sir. What engagements have I entered into, inconsistent with that preference I had too hastily, I fear, confessed for you?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The ties of hearts like mine are formed by honour only, Madam, nor could I ever take advantage of a woman's fondness to hurt her innocence, or wound her fame. Lord Seaton is a more modern kind of lover, Madam.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Lord Seaton again! What can you mean by him? Is he not married, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: For his unhappy lady's sake, as well as yours, I would he were not. The woman I once loved might then have had some excuse.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I can sustain this injury no longer—Have you not known me from my earliest youth?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, Madam, 'tis plain I did not. My fond imagination had indeed conceived a fair idea from Miss Melville's form—a heart replete with honour, love and constancy! virtues too seldom found in your frail sex, and it was vanity in me to hope I should engross so rare a treasure.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: What have I done to forfeit your opinion? But I will condescend to waive the pride of injured virtue, and tell you, Sir, that you are much deceived.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I have been so, I own, but the delirium's fled. My time is precious, now—I came hither on other purpose, Madam, and neither thought, or wished to have met you here.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Can it be possible the time should come, when Ramsay should not wish to see me!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Too many hours have I, alas, devoted to the fond impatience of seeing her I loved.—'Twas the reward I promised to myself, for toil, for danger, for the still greater pangs of absence—and how have you repaid my anxious hope!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: If the most constant, unabated tenderness and esteem could have repaid the sufferings you pretend, I should not now be deemed your debtor; nor would a lover, such as you would seem, have listened to a tale invented by some fiend to blast my honour. O Ramsay! 'tis now, alas, too plain, you never loved.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (I know not what to think—she speaks with confidence, and looks with innocence—yet Lady Seaton surely could not invent a falshood. Perhaps I have been too rash; and yet I have not time to repair my error, now. My honour is elsewhere too far engaged, at present, and the time draws near. Aside.) If ever we should meet again, Miss Melville, you will be then convinced that I have loved.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: What do you say? If ever we should meet! Do not distract me, Sir—you must not leave me till this riddle is explained, and you convinced both of my truth and love.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You must excuse me, Madam, for the present. Tho' 'tis a subject of the dearest import, I cannot now attend the explication. (Going.)

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Lord Seaton, Madam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Lord Seaton! What can his visit mean?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: O, fair dissembler! my doubts are all explained.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I come, Madam, to make my apology for having been, tho' inadvertently, the cause of any anxiety or distress to you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, I know not how I have deserved it, but you have been the source of most mortifying difficulties and distresses to me; but surely you will now be candid and generous enough to undeceive this gentleman, my friend—I know not what to stile him—Colonel Ramsay, with regard to me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: O spare yourself and him the trouble, Madam; you are mistaken, I am not deceived; I know Lord Seaton well, and know Miss Melville, too.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Blind and ungrateful as you are to love and friendship, yet for Miss Melville's sake—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: O, Sir, I doubt not but, for her dear sake, your Lordship may generously condescend to vouch her honour, with the loss of yours. (But, my Lord, you know there is another mode of satisfying me. Aside to Lord Seaton.)

div3.stage: Enter Lady SEATON, who runs to Miss Melville, and embraces her.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: My dear, my injured Charlotte, I have not words to atone the wrong I have done you, but hope in Colonel Ramsay to obtain an advocate more powerful than myself, for your forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (This surely must be illusion all! my feet are rooted to the spot I stand upon with wonder! Aside.)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My dear Lady Seaton, this is too good, too condescending, and too kind! I meant to have gone to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: No, my friend, nothing can be too much from one who has injured innocence and worth like yours by doubting of your virtue, for a moment.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I cannot comprehend this mistery—it is impossible that you should wrong me. Some spell has surely been cast round me, for Ramsay too has doubted of my truth and love.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: I, only I, who formed the charm, can break it. (My weak unjust suspicions have betrayed you into error; your censure and resentment therefore should light on me alone. To the Colonel.)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I am perplexed—What can all this mean?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: It means, my Charlotte, that my too hasty credulity has hurried me into a fault; which I can never hope you should forgive, the suspecting truth and virtue such as yours.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: To doubt of pardon, on repentance, aggravates the crime; for who that pretends not to perfection in themselves, shall dare to be implacable to another's sailings. But still I am in the dark and on the rack, to know how all this strange confusion has been conjured up.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: It arose intirely from my indiscretion in letting drop to Markam my having met you at Mrs. Frankly's. She happened to see the Colonel immediately after, and informed him of all, and perhaps more than she knew.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: At Mrs. Frankly's!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yes, at Mrs. Frankly's. Take care, Colonel; relapses are dangerous to susceptible constitutions—but I shall at more leisure account to you for so extraordinary an incident.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And I shall most patiently wait 'till you think proper to gratify merely my curiosity, in that particular.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: But mine is not to be satisfied, 'till I know how Lady Seaton should come there.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: And I am ready to indulge you.— Unhappy at your absence, my dear Charlotte, I ordered my servant to make every possible inquiry to find you out.—He saw you, by chance, going into Mrs. Frankly's, and was informed you lived there. I immediately flew to request your company, in hopes of agreeably surprising both you and the Colonel with an unexpected interview, at my house. You know the unhappy mistake occasioned then by Mrs. Frankly's behaviour, for which I again ask both my Lord's pardon, and yours.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: The nobleness of your behaviour, upon that occasion, my dear, has fully entitled you to the warmest gratitude of every person present, tho' you yet know not how highly meritorious your conduct has been, to us all.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I blush to think how I have injured your Lordship, by my rashness, and here throw myself on your generosity for forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You shall not stoop to ask it, Colonel—forgiveness we bestow upon our enemies— but we are now, and ever shall be friends.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: A gentleman seeing your Lordship's carriage at the door, inquired if you were here, and desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I shall attend him. [Exit Servant.] By the degree of familiarity he uses, I fancy it must be the Governor.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: If it be, my Lord, pray desire him to walk up.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You see, Madam, he introduces himself without a gentleman-usher.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I have been at your house, to look for you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Well, Governor, and now you have found me, what are your commands?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why, my Lord, I have both questions and commands to propose to you, d'ye see, tho' I think you have been more inclined to a game of cross-purposes, than any thing else, lately. But in plain English, I think you have behaved very ungenerously in this affair of my marriage, let me tell you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: His marriage! bless us, with whom?

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Your charge is severe, Governor; but, prithee, explain yourself, for at present I don't understand you.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
I shall make it plain enough, I warrant you—I mean, my Lord, that you have traduced
the character of a woman, whose honour I am bound to support, by every principle of a man, and I never yet put up with an affront, nor ever will, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Spoken like a champion, stout and strong, Governor.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I don't mean to act the bravo, my Lord, tho' I have faced a Nabob, at the head of his forces, before now; but all I desire of you, at present, is, that as a man of honour you will come with me and ask Mrs. Frankly's pardon, before we go to church together.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Indeed, Governor, you must excuse me from going through such a ceremony, and also for endeavouring to prevent your going through a more serious one, with a woman who is—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Don't venture to say a word against her beauty, or her virtue, my Lord, or I may not be able to command myself, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: The goodness and generosity of your own heart, Governor, render you too liable to imposition. 'Tis the nature of man to impute their own principles to others, be they good or bad.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why, I am not apt to be suspicious, that's certain; and when I met you at my pretty widow's, yesterday evening, I little thought that we had been rivals, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: To convince you, Sir, as well as the rest of this company, that I have no farther designs upon that lady, I here resign into your hands the last favour I received from hers. Read that, Governor. (Gives him Mrs. Frankly's letter.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
(Putting on his spectacles.) Hey day!— What's this! a billet to you! She has been very nimble in sending it, truly.—I thought I had made
tolerable haste in finding you, myself; but my legs are none of the best, to be sure. (Opens the letter, and reads.) Notwithstanding the inhumanity of your unkind treatment of me. You see, my Lord, she resents your behaviour, mightily. My fondness has triumphed over my resentment, and I am still weak enough to desire another interview. Why, what can all this mean! This letter should have been directed to me—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Proceed, Sir, and the mistery will soon vanish.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Tho' by seeing you again, I may possibly hazard the breaking off an advantageous match, with a man I detest. Hell and the furies! what is this? Does she mean me? the crocodile of the Nile, and the shark of the Ganges! Had she nobody to play off her monkey tricks upon, but me! Detest me!

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Compose your rage, good Governor, and finish the epistle.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Compose the devil, my Lord. Why I can't see a word more of it—I am struck blind with passion—this comes of my falling in love, forsooth, and wanting to be married to a young girl, truly.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You are cheaply off, Governor, at the expence only of a little laughing, and I think I have a right to my share of that—Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Cheaply off! now I think that, what between money and mortification, I have paid plaguy dear for my experiment—but I'll have my revenge, d'ye see, and shall go, this moment, in pursuit of it.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I must stop you, Sir, 'till your passion has subsided a little, and then I will venture to trust to your good nature.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Don't tell me of good nature, my Lord, she has made my heart as hard as a rock.

div3.stage: Enter a Servant, with a Letter to the Governor.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The messenger waits for an answer, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: What's this! another billet-doux from the traitress!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: He's in a horrid passion, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Not without reason, I assure you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: (Reading.) I shall burst with rage.— There never was such a villainous proceeding. A rascally coachmaker, a varnishing Scoundrel, I think that's his name, my Lord, threatens to arrest me for a debt I never contracted, because the fellow thought I had been married, this morning, d'ye see.—It would have been a pretty sort of incident, truly, to have happened on one's wedding-day.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I apprehend, Governor, that this would not have been the only circumstance of the kind you would have had to celebrate your nuptials, if you had married that lady.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, no, I did not fight Gentoos, Marattoes, Seapoys, and climates, d'ye see, to be bamboozled out of my money, at home.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Except by a pretty woman, Governor.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Nor by her neither, when I find her false; and so Mr. Vanish may arrest Mrs. Frankly, as soon as he pleases, for me.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: No, Sir, that debt I shall take upon myself, with pleasure, for the happiness I have received, through Mrs. Frankly's means, of knowing and esteeming Lady Seaton as I ought. Besides, a woman in distress, however incurred, is always intitled to the compassion and protection of a man of honour.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Nay, for that matter, my Lord, let me have but a little of my own way, d'ye see, and I can be as liberal as the best of you. I am passionate, but not severe; and so I forgive the injury, and shall discharge that debt; for methinks a man's mind and his means must be miserably poor, indeed, who cannot afford to give, and forgive, too—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nobly said, Sir—I find you have brought over not only the wealth, but the humanity of the East Indians, along with you.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: His tastes and manners may be foreign, perhaps, Colonel, but his good-nature and generosity are true English staple. A Briton need never go a trafficking for principles.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Well, take me as I am—I have bought some wisdom for myself, at present, for I shall not so readily believe that the women are in love with me, now, as they might have been, some thirty years ago. And so I shall think no more about a wife, for some time at least, d'ye see; unless I should renew my courtship to my old passion, Miss Melville, here.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Take care of that, Governor, lest you should make the Colonel jealous.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Nay, if you are inclined to list with him, d'ye see, I'll keep clear of you; for 'tis dangerous meddling with other men's wives, now-a-days, I hear.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If our modern marriages, Sir, were contracted upon the same principles I flatter myself ours is likely to be, a thorough love and esteem for each other, we should neither have so many libertine husbands, or faithless wives.
sp.l: True worth alone can form the charm that binds,
And rivet beauty's chains upon the mind.

div1.head: EPILOGUE,
BY A FRIEND. Spoken by Mrs. MATTOCKS.
div1.l: 'TIS very fine, indeed! all match'd I see,
All happy, all provided for, but me:
Blown up and ruin'd here—'tis a strange notion,
You'll say, but I'm resolv'd to cross the ocean;
I'll e'en equip me for the Indian route;
Seaton and Ramsay join to fit me out:
Bull says he's sure I need not then despair,
For British features bear a premium there.
Even this homely face would charm, they say,
Amongst the copper beauties of Bombay;
And she who in a croud would scarcely pass
With us, would be a Venus, at Madrass.
Pantheon, Opera, Playhouse, Fantoccini,
Farewel—I'll go, and be a Nabobini:
Or, if that scheme, perchance, should not succeed,
E'en wed a Seapoy chief, and mend the breed.
What if one's husband is a little frightful,
Where every thing besides is so delightful.
'Twill be so charming, on a summer's day,
For forty slaves to fan me as I lay,
Or on rich carpets free from noise and hurry,
Sit cross-legg'd with my spouse, and feast on Cury.
If I've a taste for baubles, my good man,
Will load me with old China and Japan.
Diamonds on diamonds heap'd, and pearly rows,
For hair, ears, neck, and breast, perhaps my nose:
No filthy hackneys there, so poor and mean,
Give me twelve Seapoys and a palanquin.
I'll keep a little squadron at my call,
And make my first grand visit in a shaul.
But must I leave my little Bull behind?
No, hang it, after all 'twould be unkind.
The fellow may be useful, he shall go;
For he can write, or underwrite, you know.
And many a worse, I heard a sweet bird sing,
Goes out a writer, and comes home a king—

l.hi: A writer here is quite another thing!

div1.l: So says our female author of to-night;
Poor soul, I hear she's in a horrid fright,
She has sent her little vessel off to sea,
And I am factor for the company—
Grant her, ye Critics, a few prosperous gales,
Let your applause but fill our swelling sails;
Do you insure her cargo safe and sound,
And Bull shall underwrite five hundred pound.
The author for your passport trembling stands,
And hopes you'll grant it under all your hands.
